posts.post_content: I wouldn't mind seeing a whole cycle of green 1 drops that produce a mana of each color, spread out throughout several sets. A green goblin that produces red, a green merfolk that produces blue, and perhaps a green hag that produces black

Posted By: Avenged7fold (2/7/2012 5:34:27 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This is the best art in magic, hands down. Every time hes on the field my eyes are glued to him, and I play the deck I have him in all the time.  
  
And as a side note, I run him over llanowar elves in my mono green. Ill tell you why. Unless your running [Predator Ooze](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Predator Ooze) or something the mana color is irrelevant in a mono green. I have never run into a situation were I needed that to be a forest mana. Also, it tricks allot of people. They think im running white and getting land screwed, and throw one of there nukes at him. You would be surprised how many times this occured.   
  
Strategic warfare and amazing art, 5/5.
posts.html:

Posted By: Hackworthy (1/23/2012 4:55:07 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
It's amazing how such a simple concept could be so potentially powerful. Not as insanely powerful as [Birds of Paradise](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Birds of Paradise)... at least, not unless you've got this in a W/G deck. W/G decks will be running this from now until the end of time.  
  
Think about it: first-turn, put out a forest and this guy. Unless the next spell you plan to cast requires three green mana (since you could put down a forest next turn) you should have near-perfect mana coverage on turn two. Moreso if you happen to put down some kind of dual land instead.
posts.html:
